findings.title: Duplicated token Ids are possible
findings.description: The mint functions allow for the creation of tokens with duplicate ids if the minter passes 0x0 as the hash for the tokens.

findings.title: Check for 0 Address in Access Control
findings.description: The ERC1155ERC721 contract uses a bouncerAdmin role with special privileges and there are no checks to prevent this new address from being set to address 0, which can lead to unwanted changes from erroneous calls.

findings.title: ERC1155 receivers can exploit gas usage
findings.description: All of the tokens standards that require a call to the receiving contract, such as ERC721, ERC777, ERC1155, ERC223, can be exploited by artificially increasing the gas usage, since the calling function doesn't limit the amount of gas passed to an external contract.

findings.title: Unify Compiler Pragmas
findings.description: Different library contracts seem to have been copied from different sources, leading to a variety of compiler pragmas.

findings.title: Avoid magic variables
findings.description: Hardcoded numbers in generateTokenId function can be replaced by declared constants to improve readability and reduce chances of mistakes.

findings.title: Misleading error message
findings.description: The error message 'supplies > 0' on the function allocateIds is misleading as it states the condition necessary for success instead of indicating the reason for failure.

findings.title: Use require instead of assert in SafeMath
findings.description: Safemath is used to validate inputs several times in the codebase, reverting the transactions through a require is the appropriate way to revert on input validation, while also reimbursing the unused gas back to the user.
